questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves is a pure sensory nerve?
questions.solution:
The olfactory nerve is a pure sensory nerve. It carries no motor fibers.

  • Olfactory: Sensory
  • Optic: Sensory
  • Oculomotor: Motor
  • Trochlear: Motor
  • Trigeminal: Both 
  • Abducent: Motor
  • Facial: Both
  • Vestibulocochlear: Sensory
  • Glossopharyngeal: Both
  • Vagus: Both
  • Accessory: Motor
  • Hypoglossal: Motor

"Both" stands for a mixed nerve (both motor and sensory).

Mnemonic: Some Say Marry Money But My Brother Says Big Brain Matters More.

questions.text: Vasopressin has maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presented with complaints of bluish-black discolouration of sclera and pinna for last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine turns black on standing as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria and results due to excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

It is an autosomal recessive condition due to deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase).

The homogentisic acid is then oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-coloured alkapton bodies, which deposits in soft tissues like cartilage and is called as ochronosis.

Image A - Normal urine
Image B - Alkaptonuria

questions.text: Dutcher bodies are seen in_____.
questions.solution:
Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma.

  • Russell bodies: Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig.
  • Mott cells/morula cells: Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of Ig
  • Flame cells: Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections
  • Thesaurocytes: Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae

Image – A binucleate plasma cell with intranuclear Dutcher cells.

questions.text: A patient presented with vomiting to medicine OPD. He has a history of eating fried rice. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Food poisoning after eating fried rice is due to Bacillus cereus.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source

Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice

Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic E.coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E.coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for drug induced Parkinson’s disease?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for drug-induced Parkinson’s disease is benzhexol.

Benzhexol is an antimuscarinic agent. Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting antimuscarinic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons. 

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Drug class

Examples 
Typical antipsychotics

Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics Metoclopramide, levosulpiride

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is?
questions.solution:
The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is the modified Y shaped incision.

In strangulation, hanging, and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, modified Y shaped incision is to be preferred, as the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised clear to give a wide approach to the neck structures.

Y-Shaped Incision: Commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards as in I-shaped incision to the symphysis pubis. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

Modified Y shaped incision: An incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. Indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck. 

I-Shaped Incision: Extends from symphysis mentii to symphysis pubis taking curve towards left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice. It is simple and convenient.

Elongated X-shaped Incision: This is a special incision used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries, which are usually missed where superficial imprints are faint, particularly when present on skin not overlying bone. This is helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death and should be practiced in cases of custodial death.

Note: This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy. For a detailed explanation about the incisions, refer to the link - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/ .

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch and then run downwards as in the “I” shaped incision.  Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): The Arnold's nerve innervates the skin over a small part of the ear and external auditory canal. In patients with chronic cough, scratching or mechanical stimulation of ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to estimate the visual field?
questions.solution:
• All the options are used to estimate the visual field.
  • Types:
    • Manual perimetry: Confrontation method, Lister’s perimeter, Campimetry (Scotometry), Goldmann’s perimeter
    • Automated perimetry: Octopus Fieldmaster, Humphrey Field Analyzer

The image given below shows Lister's perimeter.

Image: The above image shows the confrontation method for testing the visual field.

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
Demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (STAGE 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: An employee diagnosed with TB gets extended sickness benefit for:
questions.solution:
Extended sickness benefit is for 2 years.

Few important points to be known about the ESI act:

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill.
  • Employee contributes 0.75% of wages.
  • State and Central government share medical expenditure in the ratio 1:7.
  • Medical benefit: Full medical care
  • Sickness benefit: 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days.
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseaes, diabetes, Parkinsons, Myasthenia Gravis, Glaucoma, Coronary artery disease etc.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.
  • Maternity benefit: Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy.
  • Funeral expenses: Cash not exceeding Rs.15,000.

questions.text: At PHCs, vaccines are stored in:
questions.solution:
Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centres (PHCs).

ILRs are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 degree Celsius for storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs. Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ILR.

Inside the ILR there is a lining of water containers (ice packs or tubes) fitted all around the walls. When the refrigerator is functioning the water in the containers freezes and cools the cabinet. When the electricity supply fails, then the ice lining maintains the inside temperature of the refrigerator at a safe level for vaccines. Therefore, the temperature is maintained in ILR for a much longer duration than in the deep freezers and domestic refrigerators. Thus ILR is an ideal option for safe storage of vaccines.

Related Pearl: Cold Chain Equipment

Cold chain equipment : 

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator 

Solar :

  • Solar Refrigerator Battery drive
  • Solar Refrigerator Direct drive

Non electrical :

  • Cold box
  • Vaccine carrier

Transportation : 

  • Refrigerator vaccine van
  • Insulated vaccine van
  • Cold box 
  • Vaccine carrier

 

Electrical Cold Chain Equipment: 

Component

Temperature (degree Celsius)

Level

Other Comments

Walk in Freezers (WIF)

- 15 to –25 

National, State and Regional vaccine stores

Used for bulk storage of OPV

Walk in Coolers (WIC)

+2 to +8

Government Medical Store Depot (GMSD), State and Regional vaccines stores

Used for bulk storage of most vaccines in UIP

Deep Freezer (DF)

- 15 to –25 

District and Sub-district vaccines stores

Used for bulk storage of OPV and ice packs

Ice Line Refrigerator (ILR)

+2 to +8

District and Sub-district vaccines stores, PHCs

Has different temperature zones for different vaccines

Front Load Refrigerator (Domestic)

+2 to +8

Sub-district levels, hospitals. dispensaries and nursing homes

Used for all vaccines

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the chest X-ray obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

Direct lung injury-

  • Pneumonia
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • Near drowning
  • Toxic inhalation injury
  • Pulmonary contusion
  • COVID-19

Indirect lung injury-

  • Sepsis
  • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
  • Transfusions
  • Drug overdose
  • Multiple transfusions
  • Pancreatitis
  • Drug overdose

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

Exudative phase: Occurs for the first 7 days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.

Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.

Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult as a result of proteinaceous interstitial edema. Within one week, hyaline membrane occurs due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management includes :

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high-PEEP.
  • Prone ventillation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with features of tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the report of the thyroid function test in Graves' disease?

choices.text: Radioactive Iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
In Graves' disease, the level of serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high and serum T3 is high. 

Graves disease is caused by autoantibodies that bind to the thyrotropin receptor (TSHR-Ab), stimulating the growth of the thyroid and overproduction of thyroid hormone(T4 and T3). These hormones then cause negative feedback to the anterior pituitary and thus, decrease TSH levels.

And in patients with thyrotoxicosis including Graves', the RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal.

The evaluation of thyrotoxicosis is given in the flowchart below:

Related Pearl: Radioactive iodine uptake scan

Hyperthyroidism with high/ normal uptake Hyperthyroidism with low uptake
Graves’ disease Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
Toxic MNG Thyrotoxicosis factitia
Toxic adenoma Viral
TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
HCG induced thyrotoxicosis Radiation thyroiditis, Struma ovarii

questions.text: Iron absorption takes place in the _____.

choices.text: Proximal small intestine under basic condition
Proximal small intestine under acidic condition
Distal small intestine under basic condition
Distal small intestine under acidic condition

questions.solution:
Iron absorption takes place in the proximal small intestine under acidic conditions.

  • Dietary iron present as heme is efficiently absorbed; but non-heme iron is less efficiently absorbed mainly because of interference by phosphates, tannins, oxalates and other food constituents.
  • Iron is absorbed into the luminal cell in the ferrous form by DMT-1 also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp2)
  • The acidic contents of the stomach facilitate the conversion of ferric (Fe3+) iron to ferrous (Fe2+) iron by an enzyme called ferrireductase.
  • Once inside the cell, the iron can be stored as ferritin, or be released at the basolateral surface through ferroportin. 
  • Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that converts ferrous (Fe2+) iron into ferric (Fe3+) form for binding to transferrin in the plasma.

questions.text: Infection with hepatitis E virus has the highest fatality rate in which of the following populations?
questions.solution:
Fatality due to Hepatitis E is highest in pregnant women.

In the general population, hepatitis E can be complicated by fatal fulminant hepatitis in 1–2% of cases. But in pregnant women, it is raised to 20%.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound healing procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The principal behind the wound healing procedure, as shown above, is negative pressure wound therapy.

Applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds and ulcers.

The negative pressure may act by decreasing oedema, by removing interstitial fluid and by increasing blood flow. As a result, bacterial counts decrease and cell proliferation increases, thereby creating a suitable bed for graft or flap cover.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • The optimal time for performing CECT is more than 72 h after the onset of symptoms (In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis.).

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

 Balthazar Score

Balthazar Grade

Appearance on CT

CT Grade Points

Grade A

Normal CT

  0 Points
 

Grade B

 Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas  1 Point
 

Grade C

 Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation   2 Points

Grade D

 		 Fluid collection in a single location  3 Points
 

Grade E

 Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas  4 Points
Necrosis Score  

Necrosis Percentage

  

Points

No necrosis

    

0 Points

 
 

0 to 30% necrosis

    

2 Points

 
 

30 to 50% necrosis

  

4 Points

 

 
 

Over 50% necrosis

    6 Points

 

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points.

questions.text: Following a motor vehicle collision, a 30-year-old male sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen. What is the organ most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The spleen is the most common organ involved in blunt trauma injury of the abdomen.

In blunt trauma, organs that cannot yield to impact by elastic deformation are most likely to be injured, namely, the solid organs (liver, spleen, and kidneys).

For penetrating trauma, organs with the largest surface area when viewed from the front are most prone to injury (small bowel, liver, and colon). Additionally, since bullets and knives usually follow straight lines, adjacent structures are commonly injured (e.g., the pancreas and duodenum).

Deceleration injures the pedicled organs by shearing the organs from their points of attachment to the retroperitoneum (intestines and kidney).

The most commonly injured bowel in cases of blunt trauma of the abdomen is jejunum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.

The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.

Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance.

Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.

Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types.

questions.text: A G2P1 GDM patient was admitted in labor. During labor, a diagnosis of shoulder dystocia has been made. The obstetrician performed the following maneuver. This maneuver is named as _______
questions.solution:
The manoeuvre shown above is McRoberts manoeuvre.

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • This is the single most effective intervention and should be the first maneuver to be performed in shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this maneuver.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old infertile male underwent semen analysis. 
Results show: sperm concentration - 16 million/ml: pH- 7.5: volume - 2 mL: no agglutination is seen. 
Morphology shows 60% normal and 60% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
This male with sperm concentration 16 million/mL is considered to be normospermia.

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL.

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Note: Morphology is the most important factor/marker of sperm analysis.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 32%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 75% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text:
A teenage girl presented with irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair. On USG, her ovaries were enlarged. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment?
  1. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  2. Anti-androgens
  3. Lifestyle modifications
  4. Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome and anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptives (2, 3, and 4) represent the first-line treatment modalities for this condition. Laparoscopic drilling is a surgical management procedure done when medical therapy fails. 

This patient's irregular menstrual cycles, increased facial hair (signifying clinical hyperandrogenism), and increased ovarian volume are suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (Oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Ultrasound image given below shows an enlarged ovary seen in PCOS with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if,

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in marasmus and not in kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
• Children with marasmus have a voracious appetite, whereas children with kwashiorkor often refuse to eat.
  • Hypoalbuminemia is seen in kwashiorkor, which leads to edema.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age Seen in older children (6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
NO edema Edema is prominent
Voracious appetite, no apathy Apathy and loss of appetite
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen
No Fatty liver, no subcutaneous fat Fatty liver, Subcutaneous fat preserved

questions.text: The knee deformity shown below is called as _____
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation. Any increase or decrease in angle can result in knee deformities. 

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent  and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at knee joint, knee bends backwards.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with patchy hair loss, characterized by short, broken strands appearing together with long, normal hairs in the affected areas. No abnormalities of the skin or scalp are present. Biopsy shows perifollicular hemorrhage. The probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
The given history and findings suggest a diagnosis of Trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania:

  • A chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by repetitive hair pulling, leading to variable hair loss.
  • There is increased tension prior to the hair pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair pulling.
  • More common in females.
  • Trichophagy
    • Eating hair may follow the hair plucking.
    • Complications of trichophagy include trichobezoars, malnutrition, and intestinal obstruction
  • Biopsy: Perifollicular hemorrhages present.

questions.text: All of the following are used to assess difficult airway except_____
questions.solution:
ASA classification is used to quantify patient risk for anesthesia and not difficult airway

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 7 cm with head in maximum extension
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: The skin condition shown in the image below is seen in ____.
questions.solution:
• The image represents fish-like scales on the skin characteristically seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (Icthyos = Fish).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is a skin condition that happens when the skin does not shed the dead skin cells. This leads to a dry, dead skin cells that accumulate in small patches on the surface of the skin, especially on the arms and legs.
  • It is also called the "fish scale disease" due to the dead skin that accumulates in the same pattern to a fish’s scales.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

Its is a fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in Pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in Ichthyosis Vulgaris (Ichthyos = Fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery/mica-like scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Yellow/Greasy scale

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scale

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis Versicolor

questions.text: Best investigation for pulmonary embolism _____
questions.solution:
Pulmonary CT angiography /MDCT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. The dye is injected through the intravenous route.

The below figure is a CT angiography demonstrating multiple filling defects both at the bifurcation (saddle pulmonary embolism) and in the pulmonary arteries.

  • V/Q scan is done in pregnant females.
  • Investigation of choice for an aortic aneurysm is CT angiography.

questions.text: The Nuclear scan used for the detection of Meckel’s diverticulum:
questions.solution:
• Tc 99m Pertechnetate is used for detection of Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate:
    • Thyroid imaging
    • Meckel scan
    • Testicle imaging
    • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from thyroid gland
    • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.
